clinical_study.brief_title: Post-exercise Food Intake Regulation in a Hot Environment
clinical_study.official_title: Post-exercise Food Intake Regulation in a Hot Environment

brief_summary.textblock: The potential of physical activity and other non-medicinal methods for the care and prevention of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders has been insufficiently used. There is a potential influence of environmental heat in energetic balance regulation. However, the existing knowledge is insufficient to optimize physical activity programs based on the impact of exercise on energy intake regulation in hot climates. The aim of the present study is to define the major physiological determinants of short-term food intake regulation in young active and healthy men, when exposed to different levels of metabolic activity and environmental temperatures. We will thus explore the biological mechanisms related to post-exercise relative energy intake. Post-rest and post-exercise energetic compensation will be analysed in these different environmental conditions, with a special focus on the effect of the birth weight. This study should open interesting ways to define adequate nutritional and exercising programs in hot environments.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: Relative post-exercise and post-rest energy intake

secondary_outcome.description: insulin, CCK, leptin, ghrelin, pancreatic peptide

clinical_study.condition: Healthy and Physically Active Young Men

arm_group.description: Subjects will perform the intervention in a hot environment (33°C)
Subjects will perform the intervention in a neutral environment (22°C)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy and physically active men aged 18-30 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- any physical or medical problem liable to limit the subjects' ability to perform the exercise testing in safe conditions,
- ear troubles
